section.title: Overview
section.para: &PRODUCT; provides support for skinning the entire portal User Interface (UI) including your own portlets. Skins are designed to help you pack and reuse common graphic resources.

section.title: Skin Switching
section.para: Skins can be switched dynamically at runtime.
When you switch, the whole portal will be repainted and the new styles will be applied to the UI.

section.title: Skins in Page Markups
section.para: A &PRODUCT; skin contains css styles for the portal's components but also shares components that may be reused in portlets. When &PRODUCT; generates a portal page markup, it inserts stylesheet links in the page's head tag.
In the snipped code below you can see two types of links:

programlistingco.programlisting: <head> ... <link id="CoreSkin" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href="/eXoResources/skin/Stylesheet.css" /> <link id="web_FooterPortlet" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href= "/web/skin/portal/webui/component/UIFooterPortlet/DefaultStylesheet.css" /> <link id="web_NavigationPortlet" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href= "/web/skin/portal/webui/component/UINavigationPortlet/DefaultStylesheet.css" /> <link id="web_HomePagePortlet" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href= "/portal/templates/skin/webui/component/UIHomePagePortlet/DefaultStylesheet.css" /> <link id="web_BannerPortlet" rel="stylesheet" type="text/css" href= "/web/skin/portal/webui/component/UIBannerPortlet/DefaultStylesheet.css" /> ... </head>

callout.para: Portlets skin stylesheets (all others). Each portlet within the page may contribute its own style(s).

section.title: Types of Styles
section.para: The portal skin is typically made of 3 types of styles:

listitem.para: Default styles for html tags (ex div,th,td...) and the portal UI (including the sidebar and portal admin screens).
&PRODUCT; WebUI components styles are reused among different portlets.

section.para: The main portal skin stylesheet (/eXoVistaSkin/skin/Stylesheet.css)is shown below as an example:

section.title: Portlet Styles
section.para: Portlets often require additionnal styles that may not be defined by the portal skin. &PRODUCT; allows portlets to define additional stylesheets for each portlet and will append the corresponding link tags to the head.
The link ID will be of the form {portletAppName}{}$$PortletName. For example: ContentPortlet in content.war, will give id="contentContentPortlet"

section.title: How to Configure a Portal Skin
SkinService
section.para: The SkinService is an &PRODUCT; service that manages portal skin, portlet styles and portlet themes (windows borders). The code snippet below is an excerpt of the API offered by this service.
Use the skin service to register your own portal skins, portlet styles and portlet themes.

section.title: SkinConfigListener
section.para: &PRODUCT; provides a servlet listener that allows you to register your own skins and styles when your webapp starts up. The first step is to add the listener to your portlet app web.xml.

section.title: SkinConfigScript.groovy
section.para: The SkinListener looks for the groovy script file located in the war under: /WEB-INF/conf/script/groovy/SkinConfigScript.groovy

This script allows full access to the SkinService and ServletContext which are bound as scripting variables under the same name. The following script is an example. It can be found in the GateInResources.war and is used by &PRODUCT; to register the Default portal skin and some portlet themes.
The syntax of addTheme() is: addTheme(String categoryName, List<String> themesName)
So, to provide your own skin you could use the following: SkinService.addSkin("mywebapp/MyPortlet", "MyPortalSkin", "/mywebapp/skin/Stylesheet.css", ServletContext);
This simple line would register a styleesheet for a portlet named MyPortlet in a portlet app named mywebapp. The stylesheet would be used when a skin named MyPortalSkin is selected in portal.
The syntax of addSkin() is: addSkin(String module, String skinName, String cssPath, ServletContext scontext, boolean overwrite)

'overwrite' is optional, its default value is "false". If its value is true, the later call of addSkin() for the same skin key (combination of module + skinName) replaces the skin of the previous call.
Similarly, use the following to configure a particular portal:
The syntax of addPortalSkin() is: addPortalSkin(String module, String skinName, String cssPath, ServletContext scontext, boolean overwrite)

section.title: Easier css debugging
section.para: By default, CSS files are cached and their imports are merged into a single CSS file at the server side. This reduces the number of HTTP requests from the browser to the server.

The ServletContext parameter allows direct access to the CSS files from the SkinService. The optimization code is quite simple as all the CSS files are parsed at the server startup time and all the @import and url(...) references are rewritten to support a single flat file. The result is stored in a cache directly used from the ResourceRequestFilter.

Although the optimization is useful for a production environments, it may be easier to deactivate this optimization while debugging stylesheets. To do so, set the java system property exo.product.developing to true.
For example, the property can passed as a JVM parameter with the -D option in the GateIn.sh startup script: {code} EXO{code}

listitem.para: warning("This is option may cause display bugs with certain browsers like Internet Explorer")

section.title: Change portlet icons
section.para: Each portlet is represented by an icon that you can see in the portlet registry, or the webos dock. This icon can be changed by adding an image to the directory:

listitem.para: $project/portlet/myportlets/src/main/webapp/skin/DefaultSkin/portletIconsicon_name.png. To be used correctly the icon must be named after the portlet.

section.para: For example,the icon for an account portlet named AccountPortlet would be located at:

section.title: Set the default skin
section.para: The default skin of portal is called Default. To change this value (to a Mac-like skin, a Windows Vista-like skin, or an original skin), add a skin tag in the portal.xml that defines your portal:

section.title: Some CSS techniques
section.para: It is recommended that users have some experience with CSS before studying &PRODUCT; CSS. ALso, pleased read the CSS specification at
&PRODUCT; relies heavily on CSS to create the layout and effects for the UI. Some common techniques for customizing &PRODUCT;'s CSS are explained below.

section.title: Decorator pattern
section.para: The decorator is a pattern to create a contour or a curve around an area. In order to achieve this effect you need to create 9 cells. The BODY is the central area that you want to decorate. The other 8 cells are distributed around the BODY cell. You can use the width, height and background image properties to achieve any decoration effect that you want.
section.programlisting:
----------------------------------------------------------------------- | | | | | TopLeft | TopCenter | TopRight | | | | | ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | | | | | CenterLeft | BODY | CenterRight | | | | | ----------------------------------------------------------------------- | | | | | BottomLeft | BottomCenter | BottomRight | | | | | -----------------------------------------------------------------------
BODY

section.title: Left margin left pattern
section.para: Left margin left pattern is a technique to create 2 blocks side by side. The left block will have a fixed size and the right block will take the rest of the available space. When the user resizes the browser the added or removed space will be taken from the right block.
section.programlisting: | | | | | | | |<--- fixed width --->| | will expand to right ----> | | | | | | | | | | ----

section.title: How to create a new skin

step.para: Define the new skin in the WEB-INF/conf/script/groovy/SkinConfigScript.groovy file as a Resource (for example, in the project MyPortal, the resource would read; GateInResourcesMyPortal).

warning.para: The WEB-INF/conf/script/groovy/SkinConfigScript.groovy file mentioned above does not exist in EPP-5.0.ER2. The closest match is ./jboss-as/server/default/tmp/instance/02portal.war/WEB-INF/conf/uiconf/portal/webui/portal/SkinConfigOption.groovy

step.para: Place the new skin files into the skinyourSkin folder and create a new Stylesheet.css file in the same directory. This file should include lines to import all links to your CSS. For example in MyPortal project:

If no name is set for the new skin, it will be named label>. The skin name is defined in the ./jboss-as/server/default/tmpinstance/resource/skin/DefaultSkin/portal/webui/component/customization/UIChangeSkinForm/Stylesheet.css.

warning.para: The program listing below is in French. This should be translated into en-US before publication.

step.programlisting:
############################################################################# # Change Skin # #############################################################################
UIChangeSkin.action.save=Appliquer UIChangeSkin.action.close=Fermer UIChangeSkin.title.SkinSetting=Configuration des styles UIChangeSkin.MyPortal.label=Style MyPortal UIChangeSkin.Default.label=Style par d?faut UIChangeSkin.Mac.label=Style Mac UIChangeSkin.Vista.label=Style Vista Skin.title=Liste des styles Skin.left.title=Voir et s?lectionner un style

step.para: Copy the image defined above (MyPortal.jpg) to the folder ressource/skin/DefaultSkin/portal/webui/component/customization/UIChangeSkinForm/background and test your new skin.

section.title: How to create new themes

step.para: Define the new theme in WEB-INF/conf/script/groovy/SkinConfigScript.groovy in your Resource (for example, in the project MyPortal: GateInResourcesCp060508).

Place new theme files into folder skinyourSkin and create a new Stylesheet.css file in the same directory. This file should include lines to import all links to all CSS resources. For example, in the MyPortal project:

section.para: The code below illustrates the inclusion of all CSS resoucres for a new theme from the example file GateInResourcesCp060508/skin/MyPortalSkin/PortletThemes/Stylesheet.css.
